awd_titl_txt: A History of Hormones and Blood Clots
awd_abstract_narration:
This historical project will study the role of blood clotting disorders in the development of the medicine for women. It will explore the role of the body in the development of medical theory and practice. The work will be of interest to medical advocates, citizens, doctors, and public health workers. The study will provide findings that may improve doctor-patient relationships, research methods, roles of bodies in research and development, and public health activism.

The project will document the story of the development of the pill by looking at how the science was built upon the knowledge of what caused blood clots to form and how they moved throughout the body. The study will explore perceptions of risk and the asymmetry of risk by tracing the active agents in shaping pathological thought on venous blood clotting in the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries and ideas about hormonal contraception and its risks in the twentieth century. The project will use archival materials from pathologists, patients, and drug developers in order to trace the history of hormones and clotting risks.  It will illustrate the many contributions of the patients and physicians involved in this research on blood clotting from the 18th- 20th centuries.

por.por_cntn:
This project focuses on modern medical investigations of blood clots - a pathological phenomenon occurring predominantly in women's bodies. The project gives the theme of "women in medicine" an unusual twist. The intellectual merits of the study lies in its demonstration that, and how women from all walks of life contributed in various ways to modern pathological theory, hormone replacement therapies, and the development of the birth control pill. The analysis integrates multiple perspectives on the blood clot - researchers' and activists' practices, their conceptualization and visualization of clots and women's bodies, as well as cultural imagery shaping our understanding of the female body and women's illnesses. This multifaceted approach is reflected in the diversity of sources that are analyzed. Correspondences, published works and anatomical atlases produced by ninetenth-century researchers show how pathologists White, Cruveilhier, and Virchow worked with women and devised conceptions and depictions of clotting disorders. Twentieth-century primary source collections provide lying-in records, hospital reports, research in early endocrinology, and records from social activists and scientists regarding the development of the birth control pill. The project draws out the contributions of female doctors and researchers to the study of blood clots and secretions, and it considers how the very fact that women's bodies were examined constituted, shaped, and sometimes also constrained medical thinking. Research on women's bodies led to the isolation of estrogen that was used in hormone replacement therapies (HRT) and Enovid, the first birth control pill, in the twentieth century. The broader impact of the study is significant. The analysis draws attention to a lost perspective that could be most valuable for our current understanding of hormones and women's health: the holistic, non-mechanical understanding of women's bodies and women's illnesses that shaped nineteenth-century medical thinking about clotting.
